summary: A character reference letter from Isabel Sylvia Maxwell, Ghislaine Maxwell's sister, submitted to Judge Alison J. Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail application. The letter attests to Ghislaine's character, her family relationships, her reasons for staying out of public view, and her intention to remain in the United States to fight the charges.

persons.name: Isabel Sylvia Maxwell
persons.role: Sister of Ghislaine Maxwell, letter author
persons.context: The author of the character reference letter, who is Ghislaine Maxwell's older sister. She describes Ghislaine's upbringing, character, and family relationships, and offers to act as a 24/7 custodian if Ghislaine is released on bail.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the bail hearing and character reference. Her sister describes her as a loving, trustworthy person who has been unfairly vilified and who stayed in the U.S. to fight the charges against her.

persons.name: Christine Malina-Maxwell
persons.context: Identified as Isabel Maxwell's twin sister. She is co-signing a bond for Ghislaine Maxwell's bail.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom the letter is addressed.

persons.name: Robert Maxwell
persons.context: Referenced indirectly as 'our father' who had public roles in politics and publishing, influencing the family's upbringing and values.

connections.description: Isabel is the older sister of Ghislaine, having babysat her and known her all her life. She is writing a character reference and offering to be her 24/7 custodian.
Christine is co-signing a bond for Ghislaine's bail, indicating a supportive family relationship.
Referenced indirectly as 'the late Mr. Epstein', with the author contrasting Ghislaine's willingness to undergo depositions with Epstein taking the Fifth.

events.title: Son's visit to Ghislaine
events.description: Isabel Maxwell's 10-year-old son visited Ghislaine Maxwell in New York on his own, as did other nieces and nephews.

events.title: The Sun bounty offer
events.description: The UK newspaper The Sun offered a £10,000 bounty for anyone who could get them 'in front of' Ghislaine Maxwell, which the author describes as incitement to violence.

events.title: Isabel Maxwell moves to New York
events.description: Isabel Maxwell states she has been in the New York area since July 2020 to be available to support Ghislaine.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell's arrest
events.description: Referenced as the point when Ghislaine was 'summarily removed' from her stepchildren's lives. The author states Ghislaine was arrested despite never having been charged or interviewed before.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
Brazil, Israel (mentioned as false rumored locations)
keyFacts: Isabel Maxwell, Ghislaine's sister, offers to act as a 24/7 custodian for Ghislaine if she is released on bail, and states she has already relocated to New York for this purpose.

The letter claims Ghislaine Maxwell never left the United States after Jeffrey Epstein's death and was not a fugitive, but was 'laying low' due to fear of vigilantes and press intrusion, citing a £10,000 bounty offered by The Sun.
Isabel Maxwell and her twin sister Christine are co-signing a bond for $1.5 million, secured by a family home, to support Ghislaine's bail.

The author describes Ghislaine as having a loving relationship with her husband, stepchildren, and her husband's ex-wife, and states that the stepchildren's mother allowed them to travel with Ghislaine.
The letter asserts that Ghislaine Maxwell underwent many hours of deposition in civil litigation because she 'has nothing to hide,' unlike Jeffrey Epstein who took the Fifth.
